raw_text:
Godzilla gets Hollywood fame star
 
 Movie monster Godzilla has received a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame, honouring both his 50th birthday and the launch of his 28th film.
 
 An actor dressed as the giant creature breathed smoke over photographers on Monday as Godzilla received the 2,271st star on Hollywood Boulevard. "Godzilla should thank you for this historical and monumental star," said Final Wars producer Shogo Tomiyama. "But unfortunately, he cannot speak English," he added. Hollywood's honorary mayor, Johnny Grant, said: "I do hereby proclaim this Godzilla Day in Hollywood.
 
 "He's loose, he's wild, and I'm getting the hell out of here," he added. The premiere of Godzilla: Final Wars at Grauman's Chinese Theatre followed the ceremony on Hollywood Boulevard. The monster was joined by co-stars including Japanese pop star and actor Masahiro Matsuoka. Director Ryuhei Kitamura said it may not be Godzilla's final outing, as it has been billed. "That's what the producers say. But the producer's a liar," he said. "[Godzilla's] been working for the last 50 years. So, I think Godzilla just deserves a vacation." And producer Shogo Tomiyama added: "So long as Godzilla can fascinate people, I believe he will be resurrected by new generations of filmmakers in the future." Godzilla first appeared in 1954 as a prehistoric lizard woken by atomic bomb tests.
llama3.2:1b: Godzilla receives star on Hollywood Walk of Fame for 50th birthday and launch of 28th film. Actor plays monster, who breaches smoke over photographers during ceremony. Premiere of Godzilla: Final Wars follows the event.
llama3.2:3b: Godzilla received a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame to honor his 50th birthday and 28th film release, with producer Shogo Tomiyama saying "Godzilla should thank you for this historical and monumental star." The premiere of Godzilla: Final Wars followed the ceremony, with co-stars including Masahiro Matsuoka. Director Ryuhei Kitamura joked that it may not be Godzilla's final outing, but the monster was joined by fans who said they would bring back new generations of filmmakers.
gemma2:2b: Godzilla received a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame to celebrate his 50th anniversary and the premiere of his 28th film, "Godzilla: Final Wars". The ceremony involved an actor portraying Godzilla, who breathed smoke over photographers.  The event coincided with the premiere of the movie at Grauman's Chinese Theatre. Director Ryuhei Kitamura expressed hope for future Godzilla movies and producer Shogo Tomiyama believes in the monster's enduring appeal.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In 2018, an actor dressed up as Godzilla breathed smoke at the beginning of his 50th birthday on Hollywood's Walk of Fame. He received his 28th film star award and was named "Godzilla Day in Hollywood". The premiere of Godzilla: Final Wars followed the ceremony. The movie features Japanese pop singer Masahiro Matsuoka alongside director Ryuhei Kitamura. According to producers, Godzilla deserves a vacation but doesn't feel ready for a new role.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Godzilla receives Hollywood Walk of Fame star at his 50th birthday and film premiere, honoring both achievements and reigniting interest in the iconic monster.
qwen2.5:3b: Godzilla received a star on Hollywood Boulevard to celebrate his 50th anniversary and the release of his 28th film. An actor dressed as Godzilla breathed smoke at the ceremony, which honored both events. The star was unveiled in celebration of Final Wars' premiere at Grauman's Chinese Theatre. Director Ryuhei Kitamura hinted that it might not be Godzilla's last appearance. Producer Shogo Tomiyama expressed hope that Godzilla would continue to captivate audiences for future generations.

smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the original text. It does not provide any explanations or justifications for the facts presented, but rather presents them in their entirety. deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Godzilla getting Hollywood fame. Let me read through it carefully.

The main points are: Godzilla was made into a movie and got starred in Final Wars, which is on Walk of Fame. He received 2,271 stars. There was a ceremony on Hollywood Boulevard where Godzilla danced smoke over photographers because he's too shy to speak English. He's been acting since 1954 as a lizard woken by bombs. There were other actors like Matsuoka and Kitamura. Tomiyama said he doesn't know if it'll be last, but the producer claims he deserves a vacation and that new filmmakers will resurrect him.

I need to make sure I include all these key points: star naming, number of stars, ceremony details, director's comments, production plans, and his acting history.

Wait, does "final war" refer to the film? Yes. So the summary should capture that. Also, making it concise without adding extra information.
</think>

Godzilla received Hollywood Walk of Fame star number 2,271 in Final Wars, the ceremony honoring his 50th birthday and 28th film, where he danced smoke over photographers due to nervousness. He appeared as a lizard woken by bomb tests since 1954. Tomiyama said his acting journey included performances in "Final War."
tinyllama:1.1b: "Going Dzia-za-lilla: Hollywood Fame Star," Goezilla has received his Hollywood Walk of Fame star, honouring both his 50th birthday and the launch of his latest film, "Godzilla: Final Wars." An actor dressed as the giant monster was overshadowed by photographers on a press day when the producer celebrated his legacy and thanked audiences for their support. The premiere of the action-packed film in Hollywood followed, with new movie star Masahiro Matsuoka joining co-stars such as Japanese pop star and actor Masahiro Matsuoka, director Ryuhai Kitamura, and Goezilla's producer Shogo Tomiyama proclaiming that he will return at a later date.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Actor-turned-producer Shogo Tomiyama recently took to Hollywood Boulevard, where he proudly bared his stars on the iconic Walk of Fame in honor of beloved giant creature Godzilla. As reported by Variety, Godzilla has been receiving a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame since its 50th anniversary in 2017. The celebrity event took place on Monday, where finalists were honored for their contribution to the film industry.

Johnny Grant, Hollywood's honorary mayor, proclaimed the occasion with a statement about gratitude towards Godzilla for his long-lasting presence and monumental achievements. The star ceremony was attended by prominent figures in both the entertainment industry and the science fiction community. Among the attendees were actors and movie producers, as well as Japanese pop stars Masahiro Matsuoka and Ryuhei Kitamura.

Director Ryuhei Kitamura also expressed his optimism about future outings for the legendary creature. "Godzilla is a fascinating character that continues to captivate audiences," he said in an interview with Variety. "It's noteworthy that it has been working on this journey for over 50 years, so I believe there will be more opportunities for him to entertain and inspire future generations."

In addition to receiving his star, Tomiyama took the opportunity to emphasize Godzilla's importance to the science fiction genre. "Godzilla is a legendary creature that has fascinated people for decades," he said. "I think it's time for him to take a well-deserved break and restructure his actions for future endeavors."

Godzilla: Final Wars, the 28th installment in the Godzilla franchise, was officially premiered at the Grauman's Chinese Theatre on Hollywood Boulevard. The film's stars included Japanese pop star Masahiro Matsuoka and director Ryuhei Kitamura, who discussed the production of the movie with Variety.

The event brought together a diverse cast that includes an array of actors from different backgrounds, as well as eminent figures in the industry such as Steven Spielberg, James Wan, and Tom Cruise. The film also marks the return of iconic character Akira Takahata to the screen after more than 40 years since his last appearance as Godzilla's nemesis, Godzilla.

The event was an emotional reminder for fans that while the giant creature is no longer king, its legacy has endured and continues to captivate audiences with each new film.
phi:2.7b: In Hollywood, a 2,271st star was given to the movie monster, Godzilla, at a ceremony on Monday. The famous actor and producer Shogo Tomiyama gave a speech in Japanese, while Hollywood'a honorary mayor Johnny Grant proclaimed it as "Godzilla Day." The premiere of Godzilla's 28th film, Final Wars, followed the ceremony. Director Ryuhei Kitamura said that although it may not be Godzilla's last movie, he believes the monster deserves a vacation because it has been working for the last 50 years and can fascinate new generations of filmmakers in the future.
orca-mini:3b: Hollywood star was added to Godzilla's collection on Monday. The event was marked by an actor dressed up as Godzilla and smoke being blown over photographers. However, the giant creature cannot speak English. Director Ryuhei Kitamura has said that this might not be Godzilla's last outing. Producer Shogo Tomiyama believes that Godzilla deserves a break after working for 50 years. Masahiro Matsuoka, the Japanese pop star and actor who stars in the film, echoed similar sentiments.

The event was honored by Johnny Grant, Hollywood's honorary mayor, declaring it "Godzilla Day in Hollywood." Kitamura joked that Godzilla might not be retiring, as he has been active for 50 years, while producer Shogo Tomiyama suggested future generations of filmmakers would resurrect the character.
